mainEntity.name: How do I know if I'm a candidate for endoscopic spine surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text:
Candidates usually have leg-dominant pain from a herniated disc or lumbar stenosis that has not responded to six weeks of supervised physiotherapy and medication.
During consultation we review MRI scans, complete a focused neurological exam, and discuss work or sport demands before confirming the suitability of an endoscopic approach.

mainEntity.name: What recovery milestones should I expect after minimally invasive surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text:
Day 0: walk within three hours with physiotherapy support. Week 2: return to desk work once wound inspection is clear.
We schedule tele-follow ups at 48 hours, seven days, and 30 days, and the eight-week recovery roadmap below outlines each phase in detail.

mainEntity.name: How much does minimally invasive spine surgery cost with insurance?

acceptedAnswer.text:
Endoscopic discectomy packages typically range from INR 95,000 to 1,35,000 for self-pay patients including surgeon fees, OT charges, implants, and follow-up visits.
Cashless insurance approvals reduce out-of-pocket expense by roughly 12–18% once pre-authorisation is cleared. Contact us for a personalized quote based on your specific procedure and insurance coverage.

mainEntity.name: What documents do you provide for insurance or corporate approvals?

acceptedAnswer.text:
Our coordination team issues a detailed medical estimate, necessity letter, implant invoice, and operative summary aligned to TPA requirements.
Corporate employees also receive stamped medical leave summaries and fit-to-work certificates tailored to HR policies.

mainEntity.name: Do you offer teleconsultations for patients outside Hyderabad?

acceptedAnswer.text:
Yes. We provide secure video consultations for second opinions and post-operative reviews—share MRI scans via our encrypted portal or WhatsApp before the call.
International patients receive assistance with itinerary planning, visa documentation, and extended follow-up scheduling.

mainEntity.name: When can I travel or return to the gym after surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text:
Short domestic travel is generally safe after 7–10 days once pain is controlled and the wound has healed.
Gym and strength training resume after week six with progressive loading, while high-impact sports restart after clearance during the week-eight review.

mainEntity.name: How do you manage pain after endoscopic procedures?

acceptedAnswer.text:
We combine regional anaesthesia, targeted oral medication, and physiotherapy-led movement drills to keep discomfort below three on ten.
Patients receive breathing routines, cold-therapy guidance, and mindfulness resources with a 24/7 helpline for escalations.

mainEntity.name: Can I get a second opinion using my existing MRI scans?

acceptedAnswer.text:
Absolutely. Upload your DICOM files to our portal or bring the CD to clinic—we review images during consult and explain every treatment path in plain language.
You leave with a written care summary covering conservative care, surgical options, and red-flag symptoms that require urgent attention.

mainEntity.name: How quickly will I receive confirmation?

acceptedAnswer.text: Most appointment requests are confirmed within 30–60 minutes during clinic hours. We will contact you by phone or WhatsApp.

mainEntity.name: What documents should I bring?

acceptedAnswer.text: Please bring any MRI/CT scans, previous reports, and a list of current medications.

mainEntity.name: Can I reschedule after submitting?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes. If you need to change the date or time, reply to the confirmation message or call the clinic.

mainEntity.name: Do you offer teleconsultations?

acceptedAnswer.text: Teleconsultations are available for follow-ups and initial triage. Choose the teleconsult option during scheduling.

mainEntity.name: Where is the clinic located?

acceptedAnswer.text: Dr. Sayuj Krishnan practices at Yashoda Hospitals, Malakpet, Hyderabad. The address is listed on the confirmation screen.

@graph.description: Looking for the best neurosurgeon in Hyderabad? Dr. Sayuj Krishnan offers endoscopic spine surgery, brain tumor surgery, trigeminal neuralgia and epilepsy care. Safety-first, evidence-based treatment.

mainEntity.name: Is endoscopic always better than open surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: No. We choose the approach that safely achieves full decompression for your anatomy and goals. Each case is evaluated individually to determine the safest and most effective technique.

mainEntity.name: Can I get a second opinion?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes. Bring your MRI and reports; we'll review options and timelines. We encourage informed decision-making and are happy to provide second opinions.

mainEntity.name: Are older patients candidates for MISS?

acceptedAnswer.text: Many are—with careful selection, medical optimization, and clear recovery planning. Age alone is not a barrier; overall health and specific condition determine candidacy.

mainEntity.name: How do I choose the best neurosurgeon in Hyderabad?

acceptedAnswer.text: Look for fellowship training, high endoscopic case volumes, navigation/ICU support, transparent outcomes, and clear recovery plans. Dr. Sayuj practices at Yashoda Hospital, Malakpet with these safeguards in place.

mainEntity.name: What does minimally invasive spine surgery cost in Hyderabad?

acceptedAnswer.text: Endoscopic discectomy packages are typically ₹95,000–1,35,000 including surgeon fees, OT, implants, and follow-ups. Cashless insurance approval often reduces out-of-pocket expenses by 12–18% once pre-authorization is cleared.

step.text: Upload MRI/CT and a short symptom summary to hellodr@drsayuj.info or WhatsApp to confirm eligibility for an endoscopic or conservative path.

step.name: Pick a same-week slot
step.text: Coordination team schedules the earliest clinic or video slot—often same-day for nerve pain—and starts insurance pre-authorization.

step.name: Visit Yashoda, Malakpet
step.text: Bring your ID, insurance card, and medication list. The final plan and recovery roadmap are shared in writing after consultation.

schemas.name: Awake Craniotomy Guide Hyderabad | Dr. Sayuj
schemas.description: Why awake brain surgery is chosen, mapping process, recovery, and FAQs for Hyderabad patients.

mainEntity.name: Awake Craniotomy
mainEntity.followup: Most patients go home in 3–4 days and begin light activity once fatigue settles.

mainEntity.name: Why keep the patient awake?

acceptedAnswer.text: It helps protect speech and movement areas by checking function during surgery.

mainEntity.name: Is it painful?

acceptedAnswer.text: No. The scalp is numbed and sedation is tailored; you should not feel surgical pain.

mainEntity.name: How long is hospital stay?

acceptedAnswer.text: Typically 2–4 days, depending on recovery and pathology.

itemListElement.name: Does Endoscopic Spine Surgery Work for Sciatica? (Hyderabad Guide)

@graph.headline: Does Endoscopic Spine Surgery Work for Sciatica? (Hyderabad Guide)
@graph.description: Does endoscopic spine surgery work for sciatica? Learn about the 90% success rate, same-day recovery, and why it's safer than open surgery. Expert guide by Dr. Sayuj.

mainEntity.name: What is the success rate of endoscopic surgery for sciatica?

acceptedAnswer.text: Clinical studies and our own patient data show a success rate of over 90% for properly selected patients. Most patients experience immediate leg pain relief after the procedure.

mainEntity.name: Will my sciatica come back after surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: The risk of recurrence (re-herniation) is low, typically around 3-5%. Maintaining a healthy weight and following our core strengthening protocol significantly reduces this risk.

mainEntity.name: How soon can I walk after endoscopic sciatica surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Almost immediately. We encourage patients to walk within 2-3 hours of the surgery. Most patients are discharged home on the same day or the next morning.

mainEntity.name: Is endoscopic surgery safer than open surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes. Because it uses a tiny 8mm incision and does not cut muscle or remove bone, there is significantly less blood loss, lower infection risk, and faster recovery compared to traditional open laminectomy.

schemas.headline: Endoscopic Cervical Spine Surgery in Hyderabad: When It’s Recommended and What to Expect
schemas.description: A concise guide to endoscopic cervical spine surgery in Hyderabad—indications, benefits vs. fusion, recovery timelines, and safety considerations.

mainEntity.name: When is endoscopic cervical spine surgery recommended?

acceptedAnswer.text: It is considered when cervical radiculopathy persists despite 6–8 weeks of physiotherapy, medicines, and injections, and imaging shows a focal disc/foraminal stenosis correlating with symptoms.

mainEntity.name: How is endoscopic cervical surgery different from fusion?

acceptedAnswer.text: Endoscopic discectomy/foraminotomy preserves motion by removing only the offending fragment or widening the foramen. Fusion is chosen when there is instability or multilevel disease needing segmental support.

mainEntity.name: What is the recovery timeline?

acceptedAnswer.text: Most patients mobilise the same day, resume desk work in 7–10 days, and gradually return to full activity over 4–6 weeks depending on neurological recovery.

schemas.headline: Endoscopic Discectomy Cost in Hyderabad: What Affects Your Estimate?
schemas.description: Understand endoscopic discectomy costs in Hyderabad—what's included, day-care eligibility, insurance and pre-auth tips, and how we provide written estimates.
schemas.articleBody: Comprehensive guide to understanding endoscopic discectomy costs in Hyderabad, including what's included, insurance coverage, and cost factors.

mainEntity.name: Is endoscopic discectomy covered by insurance?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, most major health insurance plans cover endoscopic discectomy when it's medically indicated. Pre-authorization is typically required, and we assist with the documentation process to ensure approval.

mainEntity.name: Can I qualify for day-care discharge?

acceptedAnswer.text: Many patients with single-level disc herniation, good overall health, and adequate home support can safely go home the same day. We assess your specific case during consultation to determine if day-care is appropriate.

mainEntity.name: What if an overnight stay is needed?

acceptedAnswer.text: If medical conditions or surgical complexity require overnight observation, we'll inform you beforehand and adjust the cost estimate accordingly. Insurance typically covers medically necessary overnight stays.

schemas.headline: Endoscopic Spine Surgery Cost in Hyderabad: What Affects Your Final Bill
schemas.description: Transparent overview of endoscopic spine surgery costs in Hyderabad—what affects price, insurance, day-care eligibility, and recovery planning.

mainEntity.name: Does insurance cover endoscopic spine surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Most policies cover indicated in-patient procedures with pre-authorization. OPD consults and some diagnostics depend on your plan. We assist with documentation and pre-auth after evaluation.

mainEntity.name: Who qualifies for day-care endoscopic discectomy?

acceptedAnswer.text: Selected patients who are medically fit, have caregiver support, live nearby, and meet clinical criteria may go home the same day. Safety first—your surgeon will advise after assessment.

mainEntity.name: What factors influence the final bill?

acceptedAnswer.text: Hospital plan and room type, imaging/labs, OT time and technology (endoscope, neuronavigation, neuromonitoring), anesthesia and surgical fees, and post-op care can affect cost.

schemas.headline: Endoscopic vs Microdiscectomy: Choosing the Right Approach for Your Herniated Disc
schemas.description: Compare endoscopic and microdiscectomy techniques for herniated disc surgery—incision size, recovery, eligibility, and outcomes to help you decide.

mainEntity.name: Is endoscopic always better because it's newer?

acceptedAnswer.text: Not necessarily. Endoscopic is excellent for the right cases, but microdiscectomy remains the gold standard for complex cases. 'Newer' doesn't always mean better—the right technique for YOUR case is what matters.

mainEntity.name: Can you switch from endoscopic to open during surgery if needed?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes. In rare cases where endoscopic visualization is inadequate or unexpected findings occur, we can convert to microdiscectomy to ensure safe, complete decompression.

mainEntity.name: Will I have less back pain long-term with endoscopic?

acceptedAnswer.text: Both techniques spare most back muscles and have low rates of chronic back pain. Endoscopic may have slightly less early post-op back soreness, but long-term outcomes are very similar.

schemas.headline: Return to Work After Endoscopic Discectomy in Hyderabad: A Practical Guide
schemas.description: Week‑by‑week recovery, desk vs manual timelines, red flags, and safe progressions after endoscopic discectomy in Hyderabad.

mainEntity.name: Will I need physiotherapy?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes. After the wound check, a graded plan builds core and hip strength and posture control to reduce recurrence risk.

mainEntity.name: Can the disc re‑herniate?

acceptedAnswer.text: Recurrence can occur after any decompression. Technique and adherence to rehab reduce risk, but no approach eliminates it.

mainEntity.name: Is endoscopic recovery always faster?

acceptedAnswer.text: Many eligible patients mobilize sooner, but recovery varies. Plans are individualized to safety and symptoms.

@graph.headline: World Stroke Day 2025: Recognize Stroke Fast, Act Faster (Hyderabad, India)
@graph.description: Hyderabad-focused World Stroke Day 2025 guide on BE-FAST recognition, calling 108, thrombolysis and thrombectomy timelines, prevention checklists, rehabilitation, and Dr Sayuj Krishnan’s Stroke Code pathway.

mainEntity.name: What is a transient ischaemic attack (TIA) or “mini-stroke”?

acceptedAnswer.text: A TIA happens when a temporary clot briefly blocks blood flow to the brain. Symptoms clear within minutes or hours, but a TIA signals a high risk of a full stroke in the next days. Treat it as an emergency and seek specialist review the same day.

mainEntity.name: How is a stroke different from a seizure?

acceptedAnswer.text: Stroke is a blood-flow emergency; brain tissue is starved of oxygen. A seizure is abnormal electrical activity and may follow a stroke, but the immediate management differs. Any first-time seizure, especially with weakness or speech change, needs emergency stroke evaluation.

mainEntity.name: Can young adults or teenagers in India get a stroke?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes. Congenital heart conditions, uncontrolled hypertension, autoimmune disorders, pregnancy-related complications, sickle cell disease, COVID-19, or lifestyle risks can trigger stroke in the young. Awareness and fast hospital care matter for every age group.

mainEntity.name: What blood pressure target should I aim for to prevent stroke?

acceptedAnswer.text: Most high-risk adults benefit from keeping blood pressure below 130/80 mmHg. Individualise the goal with your physician, particularly if you live with diabetes, chronic kidney disease, or a past stroke.

mainEntity.name: Should I take aspirin the moment I notice stroke symptoms?

acceptedAnswer.text: No. Aspirin can worsen a haemorrhagic stroke. Let emergency physicians confirm the stroke type with a CT scan first—they will start antiplatelets or anticoagulants only when it is safe.

mainEntity.name: How fast must I reach a hospital in Hyderabad if stroke is suspected?

acceptedAnswer.text: Immediately. Thrombolysis works best within 4.5 hours, and mechanical thrombectomy can help selected patients up to 24 hours if imaging shows salvageable brain. Every minute of delay kills millions of neurons.

mainEntity.name: How long does stroke recovery usually take?

acceptedAnswer.text: Recovery timelines vary. Some regain independence in weeks, others need months of physiotherapy, speech therapy, and medication optimisation. Early rehab, caregiver engagement, and secondary prevention improve results.

@graph.name: How to use BE-FAST to spot a stroke
@graph.description: Step-by-step BE-FAST actions for Hyderabad families to recognise stroke and call 108 quickly.

supply.name: BE-FAST reminder card visible at home or office

step.name: Check balance
step.text: Ask the person to stand or take a few steps. Sudden dizziness, loss of balance, or leaning to one side are red flags.

step.name: Assess vision
step.text: Look for abrupt blurred vision, double vision, or loss of sight in one or both eyes.

step.name: Inspect the face
step.text: Request a smile. Drooping on one side or an uneven grin suggests facial weakness.

step.name: Test the arms
step.text: Ask the person to lift both arms. A drifting, weak, or numb arm indicates possible stroke.

step.name: Listen to speech
step.text: Have them repeat a simple sentence. Slurred, garbled, or confused speech needs urgent attention.

step.name: Call emergency services
step.text: Note the time symptoms began and dial 108 immediately. Do not self-drive; head to a stroke-ready hospital.

possibleTreatment.name: Serial MRI surveillance for small, asymptomatic tumours

mainEntity.name: Will surgery affect my hearing?

acceptedAnswer.text: Hearing preservation depends on tumour size, location, and pre-operative hearing level. We use intraoperative monitoring to maximise preservation.

@graph.name: Brain Aneurysm
@graph.description: Emergency evaluation and microsurgical or endovascular strategies for ruptured and unruptured aneurysms.

signOrSymptom.name: Sudden severe headache often described as thunderclap
Vision changes, neck stiffness, or loss of consciousness

possibleTreatment.name: Emergency stabilisation and blood pressure control

mainEntity.name: When should an unruptured aneurysm be treated?

acceptedAnswer.text: Size, location, and patient factors determine timing. Symptomatic or enlarging aneurysms require early intervention after multidisciplinary review.

mainEntity.name: What follow-up imaging is needed?

acceptedAnswer.text: Post-treatment MR or CT angiography at 6 and 12 months ensures the aneurysm remains sealed and detects recurrence early.

schemas.description: 24/7 emergency endoscopic and microsurgical evacuation of intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH), subdural hematoma, and epidural hematoma in Hyderabad with Dr. Sayuj Krishnan.

isPartOf.name: Dr. Sayuj Krishnan — Brain & Spine Clinic

about.name: Intracerebral Hemorrhage
signOrSymptom: Weakness on one side of body
possibleTreatment: ICU monitoring and blood pressure control

mainEntity.name: When is surgery needed for a brain bleed?

acceptedAnswer.text: Surgery is considered when the bleed causes significant mass effect, neurological deterioration, or is in a surgically accessible location. Small bleeds may be managed medically with blood pressure control and close monitoring.

mainEntity.name: What is endoscopic brain bleed evacuation?

acceptedAnswer.text: Endoscopic evacuation uses a small tube with a camera to remove blood clots through a minimally invasive approach. This reduces brain trauma compared to traditional open surgery and can lead to faster recovery.

mainEntity.name: How long is recovery after brain bleed surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Recovery varies based on bleed size, location, and baseline health. ICU stay is typically 3-7 days, followed by inpatient rehabilitation. Many patients show significant improvement over 3-6 months with structured therapy.

schemas.name: Brain Tumor Surgery in Hyderabad
schemas.description: Detailed guidance on brain tumour diagnosis, microsurgery, radiosurgery, and recovery with Dr. Sayuj Krishnan at Yashoda Hospital, Malakpet.

isPartOf.name: Dr. Sayuj Krishnan — Brain & Spine Clinic

mainEntity.name: Is brain tumour surgery always necessary?

acceptedAnswer.text: Surgery is advised when the benefits outweigh risks, such as relieving pressure or obtaining diagnosis. Some benign tumours can be monitored with routine imaging.

mainEntity.name: Will I need radiation after surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: High-grade tumours often need adjuvant radiotherapy or chemotherapy. Benign tumours may not require further treatment if fully removed.

mainEntity.name: How safe is awake craniotomy?

acceptedAnswer.text: Awake craniotomy is carefully planned with anaesthetists and neuropsychologists to preserve speech or motor function. Complications are rare with experienced teams.

schemas.description: Endoscopic and minimally invasive cervical decompression surgery for spinal cord compression (myelopathy) in Hyderabad with Dr. Sayuj Krishnan.

isPartOf.name: Dr. Sayuj Krishnan — Brain & Spine Clinic

about.name: Cervical Myelopathy
signOrSymptom: Hand clumsiness and difficulty with fine motor tasks

mainEntity.name: What are early warning signs of cervical myelopathy?

acceptedAnswer.text: Early signs include hand clumsiness (difficulty buttoning shirts, writing), gait unsteadiness, dropping objects frequently, and subtle numbness in hands. These symptoms progressively worsen without treatment.

mainEntity.name: Can cervical myelopathy be reversed with surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Surgery halts progression and often leads to improvement, especially when performed early. However, longstanding spinal cord damage may not fully reverse. Early intervention offers the best chance for recovery.

mainEntity.name: What is endoscopic cervical decompression?

acceptedAnswer.text: Endoscopic approach uses small incisions and HD camera to decompress the spinal cord while preserving posterior neck muscles. This minimally invasive technique reduces postoperative pain and accelerates recovery.

schemas.name: Cervical Radiculopathy Treatment in Hyderabad
schemas.description: Expert treatment for cervical radiculopathy (pinched nerve) in Hyderabad. Endoscopic keyhole surgery for arm pain, numbness, and neck pain by Dr. Sayuj Krishnan.

isPartOf.name: Dr. Sayuj Krishnan — Brain & Spine Clinic

about.name: Cervical Radiculopathy
signOrSymptom: Weakness in arm or hand muscles
Neck pain radiating to the shoulder blade
Relief when lifting the arm over the head

mainEntity.name: Does a pinched nerve in the neck require surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Not always. 90% of cervical radiculopathy cases improve with medication and physiotherapy within 6-8 weeks. Surgery is recommended if there is severe weakness, intractable pain, or if conservative treatment fails.

mainEntity.name: What is the best surgery for cervical radiculopathy?

acceptedAnswer.text: For pure nerve pinching without instability, a Minimally Invasive Posterior Cervical Foraminotomy (Keyhole Surgery) is excellent as it preserves motion and requires no fusion. For large central discs, ACDF or Disc Replacement may be better.

mainEntity.name: How long does it take to recover from pinched nerve surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Recovery is rapid. With endoscopic keyhole surgery, patients are often discharged the same day or next day. Desk work can resume in 1-2 weeks. Full return to sports takes about 6-12 weeks.

schemas.name: Degenerative Disc Disease Treatment Hyderabad | Non-Surgical & Endoscopic
schemas.description: Expert treatment for Degenerative Disc Disease in Hyderabad by Dr. Sayuj Krishnan. Non-surgical options and minimally invasive fusion for lasting relief.

isPartOf.name: Dr. Sayuj Krishnan - Neurosurgeon in Hyderabad

mainEntity.name: Degenerative Disc Disease Treatment
mainEntity.description: Expert treatment for Degenerative Disc Disease in Hyderabad by Dr. Sayuj Krishnan. Non-surgical options and minimally invasive fusion for lasting relief.

mainEntity.name: What is Degenerative Disc Disease (DDD)?

acceptedAnswer.text: DDD is not actually a 'disease' but a natural aging process where the spinal discs lose hydration (drying out) and height. This can lead to instability, nerve compression, and chronic back pain.

mainEntity.name: Can degenerated discs be repaired without surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: While we cannot 'regrow' a disc, we can eliminate the pain it causes. 90% of patients achieve long-term relief through targeted physiotherapy, lifestyle changes, and precise nerve root blocks, without needing surgery.

mainEntity.name: What is 'Black Disc' disease?

acceptedAnswer.text: On an MRI scan, a healthy disc looks white (hydrated). A degenerated disc looks dark or black because it has lost water content. This is a common finding and doesn't always require surgery unless it causes severe pain.

mainEntity.name: Is surgery safe for elderly patients with DDD?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, we specialize in 'Awake Spine Surgery' and endoscopic techniques for patients over 60. This avoids the risks of general anesthesia and minimizes recovery time, making it safe for elderly patients with co-morbidities.

mainEntity.name: What are the symptoms of lumbar degenerative disc disease?

acceptedAnswer.text: Common symptoms include chronic low back pain that worsens with sitting, pain radiating to the hips or thighs, and occasional 'locking' of the back. Numbness or weakness in the legs indicates nerve involvement.

mainEntity.name: How does Dr. Sayuj treat DDD?

acceptedAnswer.text: We follow a step-ladder approach: 1) Medications & Physio to strengthen the spine. 2) Radiofrequency Ablation (RFA) to silence painful nerves. 3) Endoscopic surgery or Fusion only if instability is severe.

mainEntity.name: What is the cost of DDD treatment in Hyderabad?

acceptedAnswer.text: Conservative care starts from ₹5,000. Pain interventions like RFA cost ₹40,000–₹60,000. If surgical fusion (TLIF) is needed, it ranges from ₹2.5 Lakhs to ₹4.5 Lakhs depending on the implants and hospital category.

mainEntity.name: Does walking help degenerative disc disease?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, gentle walking increases blood flow to the spine and strengthens the muscles that support your back. We recommend 20-30 minutes of walking daily, avoiding high-impact activities.

mainEntity.name: When is spinal fusion necessary for DDD?

acceptedAnswer.text: Fusion is reserved for cases where the spine is 'unstable' (bones slipping over each other, like Spondylolisthesis) or when simple decompression isn't enough to relieve the pain.

mainEntity.name: Can I ignore Degenerative Disc Disease?

acceptedAnswer.text: Ignoring it can lead to worsening stiffness and nerve damage. Early intervention with physiotherapy can slow the progression and prevent the need for major surgery later in life.

mainEntity.name: What is a compression fracture?

acceptedAnswer.text: It is a collapse of a vertebra (back bone), usually caused by osteoporosis (weak bones). It often happens after a minor fall or even lifting something heavy in elderly patients.

mainEntity.name: What is Vertebroplasty (Cement Injection)?

acceptedAnswer.text: Vertebroplasty is a minimally invasive procedure where medical-grade bone cement is injected into the fractured vertebra to stabilize it and stop the pain immediately.

mainEntity.name: Is surgery always needed for spine fractures?

acceptedAnswer.text: No. Stable fractures without severe pain can heal with bed rest, bracing, and calcium medication. Surgery (Vertebroplasty) is advised if pain is severe or the bone collapse is worsening.

mainEntity.name: Is Vertebroplasty safe for elderly patients?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, it is specifically designed for the elderly. It is done under local anesthesia or mild sedation, takes less than an hour, and avoids major open surgery risks.

mainEntity.name: How fast is recovery after Kyphoplasty/Vertebroplasty?

acceptedAnswer.text: Pain relief is often immediate (within hours). Patients can usually walk the same evening and go home the next day.

schemas.name: Sciatica Treatment in Hyderabad | Non-Surgical & Endoscopic Options
schemas.description: Expert sciatica treatment in Hyderabad by Dr. Sayuj Krishnan. 90% of patients recover without surgery. Get a precise diagnosis and non-surgical relief plan.

isPartOf.name: Dr. Sayuj Krishnan - Neurosurgeon in Hyderabad

mainEntity.name: Sciatica Treatment
mainEntity.description: Expert sciatica treatment in Hyderabad by Dr. Sayuj Krishnan. 90% of patients recover without surgery. Get a precise diagnosis and non-surgical relief plan.

mainEntity.name: What is sciatica?

acceptedAnswer.text: Sciatica is not a condition itself, but a symptom of an underlying problem. It refers to pain that radiates along the path of the sciatic nerve, which branches from your lower back through your hips and buttocks and down each leg.

mainEntity.name: Can sciatica be cured without surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes. In fact, 90% of our patients recover completely with non-surgical methods like targeted nerve blocks, medication, and specialized physiotherapy. Surgery is a last resort, not the first step.

mainEntity.name: What causes sciatica?

acceptedAnswer.text: The most common cause is a herniated (slipped) disc compressing the nerve root. Other causes include spinal stenosis (narrowing of the spine), bone spurs, or rarely, a tumor or diabetic neuropathy.

mainEntity.name: Does sciatica always require surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: No. 80-90% of sciatica cases resolve with conservative treatments like medication, physiotherapy, and rest. Surgery (endoscopic discectomy) is only recommended if pain persists after 6 weeks or if there is severe weakness.

mainEntity.name: How is sciatica diagnosed?

acceptedAnswer.text: Diagnosis starts with a physical exam to check muscle strength and reflexes (Straight Leg Raise test). An MRI scan is the gold standard to visualize the nerve compression and identify the exact cause.

mainEntity.name: What are the warning signs of severe sciatica?

acceptedAnswer.text: Seek immediate medical attention if you experience: sudden severe pain after an accident, loss of bowel/bladder control (Cauda Equina Syndrome), or progressive weakness/numbness in the leg.

mainEntity.name: What is the cost of sciatica treatment in Hyderabad?

acceptedAnswer.text: The cost depends on the procedure. A simple nerve root block may cost ₹15,000–₹25,000, while endoscopic spine surgery typically ranges from ₹1.5 Lakhs to ₹2.5 Lakhs depending on the hospital category and implant requirements.

mainEntity.name: Is my office chair causing my sciatica?

acceptedAnswer.text: Prolonged sitting is a major risk factor. Poor ergonomics can increase pressure on lumbar discs by 40%, potentially triggering or worsening sciatica. We recommend ergonomic adjustments and taking breaks every 30 minutes.

mainEntity.name: Is it Sciatica or Piriformis Syndrome?

acceptedAnswer.text: True sciatica comes from the spine (nerve root compression). Piriformis syndrome is when a muscle in the buttock compresses the sciatic nerve. Dr. Sayuj uses specific clinical tests to distinguish them, as treatments differ significantly (spine decompression vs. muscle release).

mainEntity.name: Is sciatica common during pregnancy?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, up to 50% of women experience some sciatic pain during pregnancy due to the baby's weight and postural changes. We offer safe, medication-free physiotherapy protocols to manage this pain without risking the baby's health.

mainEntity.name: Can I drive with sciatica?

acceptedAnswer.text: Driving often worsens sciatica due to the vibration and leg position. We recommend short trips, using a lumbar support cushion, and stopping every 30 minutes to stretch. If you have foot weakness (foot drop), do not drive.

mainEntity.name: What exercises should I avoid with sciatica?

acceptedAnswer.text: Avoid heavy hamstring stretches, straight leg raises, and twisting movements like golf until cleared by a physio. These can increase nerve tension.

mainEntity.name: Slip Disc Treatment
mainEntity.description: Expert slip disc treatment in Hyderabad. From conservative care to endoscopic discectomy. Same-day discharge, minimal pain. Book consultation with Dr. Sayuj Krishnan.

mainEntity.name: What is a slip disc and how is it treated?

acceptedAnswer.text: A slip disc (herniated disc) occurs when the soft center of a spinal disc pushes through a crack in the outer ring. Treatment begins with conservative measures like medication and physiotherapy. If symptoms persist, Dr. Sayuj Krishnan specializes in endoscopic discectomy, a minimally invasive procedure for lasting relief.

mainEntity.name: Do I always need surgery for a slip disc?

acceptedAnswer.text: No. 80-90% of slip disc patients recover with conservative treatment (medications, rest, physiotherapy) within 6 weeks. Surgery is only recommended if there is severe pain, weakness, or no improvement after non-surgical care.

mainEntity.name: How long does endoscopic discectomy take?

acceptedAnswer.text: The endoscopic discectomy procedure typically takes 45-60 minutes. Most patients can walk the same day and return to desk work within 1-2 weeks. Physical jobs may require 4-8 weeks with a graded return plan.

mainEntity.name: What are the benefits of endoscopic discectomy over traditional surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Endoscopic discectomy offers several advantages: smaller incision (6-8mm vs 3-4 inches), less muscle damage, minimal blood loss, same-day discharge, faster recovery, and reduced risk of complications. The procedure preserves normal spinal anatomy while effectively treating the herniated disc.

mainEntity.name: Who is a candidate for endoscopic discectomy?

acceptedAnswer.text: Candidates include patients with leg-dominant pain from herniated discs who haven't improved with conservative treatment (medications, physiotherapy). Dr. Krishnan evaluates each case individually, considering MRI findings, symptoms, and overall health to determine the best treatment approach.

mainEntity.name: What is the success rate of endoscopic discectomy?

acceptedAnswer.text: Endoscopic discectomy has a high success rate of 85-95% for appropriate candidates. Success depends on proper patient selection, surgeon experience, and following post-operative care instructions. Dr. Krishnan's extensive experience in minimally invasive spine surgery ensures optimal outcomes.

mainEntity.name: What is lumbar canal stenosis?

acceptedAnswer.text: It is a narrowing of the spinal canal in the lower back. This narrowing squeezes the nerves that travel to your legs, causing pain, heaviness, or numbness when walking.

mainEntity.name: Why do my legs hurt only when I walk?

acceptedAnswer.text: This is called "Neurogenic Claudication". When you stand or walk, your spine arches slightly, narrowing the canal further and pinching the nerves. Sitting or bending forward opens the canal and relieves the pain.

mainEntity.name: Is surgery necessary for stenosis?

acceptedAnswer.text: Surgery is advised if your walking distance is significantly reduced (e.g., you can't walk more than 10 minutes) or if you have numbness/weakness. Mild cases can be managed with medication and exercises.

mainEntity.name: What is the success rate of stenosis surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Decompression surgery has a very high success rate (over 90%) for relieving leg pain and improving walking ability. Back pain relief varies depending on other factors.

mainEntity.name: How is Micro-Decompression different from Laminectomy?

acceptedAnswer.text: Micro-decompression uses a microscope and a smaller incision to remove only the bone spur pressing the nerve, preserving spinal stability. Traditional laminectomy removes more bone and muscle.

about.name: Spinal Tumor
signOrSymptom: Loss of sensation or weakness in limbs
Loss of bowel or bladder control

mainEntity.name: Are all spine tumours cancerous?

acceptedAnswer.text: No. Many spinal tumours are benign (non-cancerous) but can still cause paralysis by compressing the spinal cord. Others may be metastases from cancer elsewhere.

mainEntity.name: Is paralysis after surgery common?

acceptedAnswer.text: With modern intraoperative neuromonitoring and microsurgical techniques, the risk of new deficits is significantly minimised. The goal is often to prevent paralysis.

mainEntity.name: How long is the recovery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Hospital stay is typically 4-7 days depending on whether spinal fusion was performed. Full rehabilitation may take weeks to months.

mainEntity.name: Will I need spinal fusion?

acceptedAnswer.text: Spinal fusion is only recommended when a tumour or its removal makes the spine unstable. Your surgeon will assess tumour location, bone involvement, and your overall health to decide whether fusion is necessary in your case.

mainEntity.name: How do you protect nerves during surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Nerves are protected using an operating microscope, fine microsurgical instruments, and continuous intraoperative neuromonitoring of spinal cord and nerve function. This helps the surgeon separate tumour from healthy tissue and detect any stress on the nerves early.

mainEntity.name: What is the role of radiosurgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Stereotactic radiosurgery is a focused form of radiotherapy used for selected spinal tumours, such as small residual or inoperable lesions and certain metastatic spine tumours. It delivers high-dose radiation precisely to the tumour while limiting exposure to the spinal cord.

mainEntity.name: Do you treat metastatic spine tumours?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes. Metastatic spine tumours are managed in a multidisciplinary way, combining surgery when needed with radiation and systemic cancer treatments. The aim is to relieve spinal cord compression, stabilise the spine, and improve quality of life.

mainEntity.name: Do I really need surgery for spondylolisthesis?

acceptedAnswer.text: Not always. Surgery is usually recommended only if you have Grade 3/4 slips, or if you have Grade 1/2 slips with persistent nerve pain/weakness that hasn't improved after 6 weeks of rehabilitation and medication.

mainEntity.name: What is the cost of spondylolisthesis surgery in Hyderabad?

acceptedAnswer.text: The cost typically ranges from ₹2.5 Lakhs to ₹3.5 Lakhs for Minimally Invasive TLIF (Fusion). This includes hospital stay, implants, and surgeon fees. Open surgery may cost slightly less, but recovery is longer.

mainEntity.name: How long is the recovery after spinal fusion?

acceptedAnswer.text: With MIS-TLIF, patients usually walk the next day. Desk work can often resume in 3-4 weeks. Complete bone fusion takes 3-6 months, during which heavy lifting is restricted.

mainEntity.name: Can spondylolisthesis be cured with exercise?

acceptedAnswer.text: Grade 1 slips can often be stabilized with core strengthening exercises. While the slip itself won't reverse, the pain can vanish completely, avoiding the need for surgery.

mainEntity.name: Is MIS TLIF better than open surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, for most patients. MIS TLIF involves smaller incisions, less muscle cutting, less blood loss, and a shorter hospital stay compared to traditional open fusion.

mainEntity.description: Explore medicines, microvascular decompression, radiosurgery and percutaneous options for trigeminal neuralgia in Hyderabad with Dr. Sayuj Krishnan.

mainEntity.name: Is trigeminal neuralgia curable?

acceptedAnswer.text: Many patients achieve sustained pain relief with procedures such as microvascular decompression or radiosurgery. Recurrence can happen, so structured follow-up remains important.

mainEntity.name: How long does Gamma Knife radiosurgery take to work?

acceptedAnswer.text: Relief is gradual. Most people notice improvement two to eight weeks after treatment, and medicines are tapered only when symptoms remain controlled.

mainEntity.name: What are the risks of MVD?

acceptedAnswer.text: Serious complications are uncommon, particularly with neuromonitoring. Potential risks include hearing changes, facial numbness, or cerebrospinal fluid leak, all discussed before surgery.

mainEntity.name: Can trigeminal neuralgia return after treatment?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, especially years later. Recurrence does not rule out further treatment—repeat MVD, radiosurgery, or percutaneous options can still help.

mainEntity.name: Is medication enough for everyone?

acceptedAnswer.text: Medicines control pain for many people, but side effects or breakthrough pain may prompt procedures. We decide together based on symptom control and MRI findings.

about.name: Endoscopic Spine Surgery
about.description: Minimally invasive spine procedures using advanced endoscopic techniques

about.name: Epilepsy Surgery
about.description: Comprehensive surgical treatment for drug-resistant epilepsy

mainEntity.name: What makes endoscopic surgery different from traditional surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Endoscopic surgery uses small incisions (8-10mm) and specialized instruments to access and treat spine conditions. This results in less muscle damage, reduced pain, faster recovery, and lower risk of complications compared to traditional open surgery.

mainEntity.name: How long is the recovery time for endoscopic procedures?

acceptedAnswer.text: Recovery times vary by procedure, but most endoscopic spine surgeries allow patients to return to desk work within 1-2 weeks and full activities within 4-6 weeks. This is significantly faster than traditional open surgery.

mainEntity.name: Are all patients candidates for minimally invasive surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Not all patients are suitable for endoscopic procedures. We evaluate each case individually based on MRI findings, symptoms, and overall health. Some complex cases may require traditional open surgery for optimal outcomes.

mainEntity.name: What should I expect during my consultation?

acceptedAnswer.text: During your consultation, Dr. Sayuj will review your MRI scans, discuss your symptoms, explain treatment options, and develop a personalized treatment plan. Bring your imaging studies and a list of current medications.

mainEntity.name: Who is a good candidate for awake spine surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Patients with cardiac, pulmonary, or metabolic risks who should avoid prolonged general anaesthesia, elderly patients, and those needing short endoscopic decompressions or discectomy often benefit most.

mainEntity.name: What type of anaesthesia is used?

acceptedAnswer.text: We combine spinal or epidural anaesthesia with light conscious sedation. You breathe on your own, feel no pain, and we monitor comfort throughout the case.

mainEntity.name: Is recovery faster than conventional surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes. Awake endoscopic approaches use 6–8 mm incisions with minimal muscle disruption. Most patients sit up within hours and go home the same day or after one night of observation.

mainEntity.name: Brain Tumor Surgery
mainEntity.description: Advanced brain tumor surgery in Hyderabad with Dr. Sayuj Krishnan. High success rates with Neuronavigation & Awake Craniotomy for faster recovery. Trusted Neuro-Oncology care.

mainEntity.name: How quickly can surgery be scheduled after diagnosis?

acceptedAnswer.text: Urgent cases with progressive neurological deficits are prioritised within 48-72 hours. Elective cases are scheduled after tumour board discussions and pre-anaesthesia evaluation, often within 5-7 working days.

mainEntity.name: Do you treat patients referred from other hospitals?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes. We regularly handle referrals for complex skull base tumours and recurrent gliomas. Bring imaging, histopathology reports, and prior treatment summaries for a complete review.

mainEntity.name: Is a craniotomy always required?

acceptedAnswer.text: Not always. Some lesions are best managed with stereotactic biopsy, radiosurgery, or endoscopic skull base approaches. Surgical planning is individualised based on tumour type, size, and location.

mainEntity.name: How long does recovery take after brain tumor surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Most patients spend 1-2 days in the ICU for monitoring and move to the ward for another 3-4 days. You can usually return to light daily activities within 2-3 weeks, though full recovery depends on the specific tumor type and location.

mainEntity.name: What is the cost of brain tumor surgery in Hyderabad?

acceptedAnswer.text: The cost of brain tumor surgery varies significantly based on tumor complexity, ICU stay duration, and technology used (neuronavigation, monitoring). Biopsies may start from ₹1,00,000, while complex craniotomies can range higher. We provide transparent estimates after scan review.

mainEntity.name: What is cervical disc replacement?

acceptedAnswer.text: Cervical disc replacement (ADR) is a surgery where a damaged spinal disc is removed and replaced with an artificial device that mimics natural motion, unlike fusion which locks the bones.

mainEntity.name: Is replacement better than fusion?

acceptedAnswer.text: For younger patients with healthy joints, replacement is often better as it preserves neck movement and prevents "adjacent segment disease" (wear and tear on other discs).

mainEntity.name: Am I a candidate for disc replacement?

acceptedAnswer.text: You are likely a candidate if you have arm pain/weakness from a soft disc herniation but do not have severe arthritis, instability, or osteoporosis.

mainEntity.name: How long does the artificial disc last?

acceptedAnswer.text: Modern artificial discs are designed to last 40-50 years, making them a long-term solution for younger active patients.

mainEntity.name: What is the recovery time?

acceptedAnswer.text: Recovery is faster than fusion because no bone knitting is required. Most patients go home in 1-2 days and return to light work in 2-3 weeks.

mainEntity.name: What is Cervical Endoscopic Spine Surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: It is an advanced minimally invasive technique to treat neck pain and arm pain (radiculopathy) caused by disc herniations or stenosis. Using a high-definition endoscope and micro-instruments through a tiny incision (<1cm), Dr. Sayuj removes the compression while preserving the stability of the spine.

mainEntity.name: Does this surgery require fusion (screws and plates)?

acceptedAnswer.text: In many cases, NO. The primary advantage of endoscopic cervical foraminotomy is that it preserves the natural motion of your neck. Unlike ACDF (Anterior Cervical Discectomy and Fusion), we do not need to place screws, plates, or cages.

mainEntity.name: Is it safe for voice and swallowing?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, especially with the posterior approach. Traditional anterior neck surgery carries a small risk of temporary hoarseness or difficulty swallowing. The posterior endoscopic approach enters from the back of the neck, completely avoiding the throat and vocal cords.

mainEntity.name: What conditions can be treated?

acceptedAnswer.text: It is highly effective for Cervical Radiculopathy (pinched nerve causing arm pain), Foraminal Stenosis, and Soft Disc Herniations. It may not be suitable for large central calcified discs or severe spinal cord compression (myelopathy), which may require other approaches.

mainEntity.name: How fast is the recovery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Patients typically go home the same day or the next morning. You can walk and move your neck gently immediately after surgery. Most patients return to desk jobs within 1 week and driving within 2 weeks.

mainEntity.name: Why choose Dr. Sayuj for this procedure?

acceptedAnswer.text: Dr. Sayuj Krishnan is one of the few neurosurgeons in Hyderabad proficient in both Anterior and Posterior Endoscopic Cervical techniques. His "Motion Preservation" philosophy prioritizes saving your natural spinal function whenever possible.

mainEntity.name: What should I compare when choosing a neurosurgeon in Hyderabad?

acceptedAnswer.text: Review surgeon experience, minimally invasive options, outcomes, infection rates, and follow-up support—not just hospital brand.

mainEntity.name: Do all hospitals offer endoscopic spine surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: No. Endoscopic/MISS programs depend on surgeon training and equipment. Ask specifically about endoscopic options and outcomes.

schemas.name: Cooled Radiofrequency Ablation
schemas.description: Advanced minimally invasive procedure using cooled radiofrequency energy to create larger nerve lesions for long-lasting chronic pain relief

mainEntity.name: How long does cooled radiofrequency ablation pain relief last?

acceptedAnswer.text: Cooled radiofrequency ablation typically provides pain relief lasting 12-24 months, significantly longer than traditional RFA (6-12 months). Some patients may experience relief for even longer periods.

mainEntity.name: Is cooled RFA different from traditional RFA?

acceptedAnswer.text: Cooled RFA uses water-cooled probes that create larger lesions (up to 8mm vs 2-3mm) while preventing tissue charring. This results in more comprehensive nerve coverage, longer-lasting pain relief, and higher success rates compared to traditional RFA.

mainEntity.name: When will I feel pain relief after cooled RFA?

acceptedAnswer.text: Most patients begin to experience pain relief within 1-2 weeks after the procedure. Maximum pain relief is typically achieved within 2-4 weeks as the nerve lesion fully develops.

mainEntity.name: What conditions can be treated with cooled radiofrequency ablation?

acceptedAnswer.text: Cooled RFA is effective for treating facet joint pain (cervical, thoracic, lumbar), sacroiliac joint pain, and certain types of trigeminal neuralgia. It's particularly beneficial for chronic pain that hasn't responded to conservative treatments.

mainEntity.name: Endoscopic Discectomy
mainEntity.description: Expert endoscopic discectomy for herniated discs in Hyderabad. Same-day surgery, faster recovery, less pain with Dr. Sayuj Krishnan.

mainEntity.name: How long does endoscopic discectomy surgery take?

acceptedAnswer.text: Endoscopic discectomy typically takes 45-90 minutes depending on the complexity of the case. The procedure is performed under general anesthesia and uses a small endoscope to remove the herniated disc material through a tiny 8-10mm incision.

mainEntity.name: What is the recovery time after endoscopic discectomy?

acceptedAnswer.text: Most patients can return to desk work within 1-2 weeks after endoscopic discectomy. Physical jobs may require 4-8 weeks. The procedure allows for same-day or 1-night hospital stay, with most patients walking the same day. Full recovery typically takes 4-6 weeks.

mainEntity.name: Is endoscopic discectomy better than open surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Endoscopic discectomy offers several advantages over traditional open surgery: smaller incision (8-10mm vs 3-4cm), less muscle damage, reduced blood loss, lower infection risk, faster recovery, and same-day discharge. Success rates are comparable (85-90%) with less post-operative pain.

mainEntity.name: What are the risks of endoscopic discectomy?

acceptedAnswer.text: Endoscopic discectomy is generally safe with low complication rates. Potential risks include infection (<1%), nerve injury (<1%), dural tear (<2%), and recurrence (5-10%). Dr. Sayuj Krishnan's experience with 1000+ endoscopic procedures results in excellent safety outcomes.

mainEntity.name: When should I see a neurosurgeon for back pain?

acceptedAnswer.text: If you have persistent back or leg pain, numbness or weakness that isn’t improving with rest and physiotherapy, or if you experience loss of bowel or bladder control, consult a neurosurgeon. Early evaluation in Hyderabad can prevent nerve damage and may allow for minimally invasive treatment.

mainEntity.name: What should I expect on the day of endoscopic spine surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Most cases are day-care procedures. You arrive for pre-op checks, undergo keyhole surgery, and begin walking within hours. Discharge is usually the same evening or next morning with a recovery plan.

mainEntity.name: Is endoscopic spine surgery painful?

acceptedAnswer.text: Endoscopic spine surgery uses tiny incisions and causes less tissue disruption than traditional open surgery. Most patients report manageable discomfort controlled with oral pain medication and are able to walk the same day.

mainEntity.name: How soon can I walk after endoscopic disc surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Patients typically begin walking within a few hours of endoscopic discectomy. Many return to desk work within 1–2 weeks, while heavy labour may require 4–8 weeks of graded recovery.

mainEntity.name: What is the success rate of endoscopic discectomy?

acceptedAnswer.text: For appropriately selected patients, endoscopic discectomy has a high success rate (around 85–95%) in relieving leg pain and numbness. Success depends on proper diagnosis, surgeon experience and adherence to post‑operative care instructions.

mainEntity.name: When should I seek a second opinion for spine surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: If surgery feels rushed, the diagnosis is unclear, or you want to confirm a minimally invasive alternative, a second opinion helps align the plan with your goals.

mainEntity.name: Can I share MRI scans digitally for review?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes. You can send DICOM files or reports; we review them before consult to suggest alternatives or confirm the plan.

mainEntity.name: What is the difference between Vertebroplasty and Kyphoplasty?

acceptedAnswer.text: Vertebroplasty involves injecting cement directly into the fractured bone to stabilize it. Kyphoplasty uses a balloon first to create a cavity and restore height before injecting cement. Kyphoplasty is better if there is significant height loss.

mainEntity.name: Is general anaesthesia required?

acceptedAnswer.text: Usually, no. Both procedures can be performed under local anaesthesia with mild sedation (Monitored Anaesthesia Care), making it safe for elderly patients with other health issues.

mainEntity.name: How quickly does the pain go away?

acceptedAnswer.text: Most patients experience significant pain relief within 2 to 24 hours after the procedure. The cement hardens in minutes, providing immediate stability.

mainEntity.name: Are these procedures safe for elderly patients?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, these are specifically designed for elderly patients with osteoporosis. Since they are minimally invasive and avoid general anaesthesia, they are very safe even for those 80+ years old.

mainEntity.name: Can I walk after surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, we encourage patients to walk within 2-3 hours after the procedure. Early mobilization helps prevent complications like blood clots and pneumonia.

mainEntity.name: What is the cost of Vertebroplasty in Hyderabad?

acceptedAnswer.text: The cost typically ranges from ₹1.1 Lakh to ₹1.4 Lakh depending on the number of levels and type of cement used. Insurance usually covers this procedure.

mainEntity.name: What is lumbar laminectomy?

acceptedAnswer.text: Lumbar laminectomy is a decompression surgery that creates space for the spinal cord and nerves by removing the lamina (the back part of the vertebra). It is commonly used to treat spinal stenosis.

mainEntity.name: Is laminectomy a major surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: It is a common spine procedure. While traditional open laminectomy is a significant surgery, we now often perform "Endoscopic ULBD" (Unilateral Laminotomy for Bilateral Decompression), which is minimally invasive and has a much faster recovery.

mainEntity.name: How long does recovery take?

acceptedAnswer.text: For traditional laminectomy, full recovery takes 4-6 weeks. With endoscopic techniques, patients often return to desk work in 2 weeks. Walking is encouraged immediately after surgery.

mainEntity.name: Will my back pain go away completely?

acceptedAnswer.text: Laminectomy is primarily designed to relieve LEG pain (sciatica) and heaviness caused by nerve compression. While back pain often improves, the main goal is to stop the nerve damage and improve walking distance.

mainEntity.name: What are the risks?

acceptedAnswer.text: Risks include infection, bleeding, dural tear (spinal fluid leak), or nerve injury. Dr. Sayuj uses high-magnification microscopes or endoscopes to minimize these risks significantly.

mainEntity.name: What is the cost of microdiscectomy in Hyderabad?

acceptedAnswer.text: The cost of microdiscectomy in Hyderabad typically ranges from ₹2,20,000 to ₹3,50,000. This varies based on room category, hospital choice, and whether implants (if any) are required. It is generally slightly more affordable than fully endoscopic options but offers excellent outcomes.

mainEntity.name: Is microdiscectomy covered by insurance?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, microdiscectomy is a standard, medically necessary procedure for herniated discs and is covered by almost all health insurance policies in India. We offer cashless facilities at Yashoda Hospital.

mainEntity.name: How does microdiscectomy cost compare to open surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Microdiscectomy may cost ₹20,000–₹40,000 more than traditional open laminectomy due to the use of an operating microscope and specialized instrumentation, but the faster recovery and reduced hospital stay often make the total cost comparable.

mainEntity.name: Minimally Invasive Spine Surgery
mainEntity.description: Expert endoscopic spine surgery in Hyderabad with Dr. Sayuj Krishnan. Minimally invasive procedures with same-day discharge at Yashoda Hospital Malakpet.

mainEntity.name: What is Minimally Invasive Spine Surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Minimally invasive spine surgery (MISS) uses smaller incisions and endoscopic or microscopic instruments to reach the spine while gently moving muscles instead of cutting them. This approach reduces tissue trauma, pain, and blood loss compared to traditional open surgery.

mainEntity.name: What conditions can be treated with Minimally Invasive Spine Surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: MISS is recommended when conservative treatments no longer control symptoms from conditions such as herniated discs, spinal stenosis, foraminal stenosis, spinal deformities like scoliosis, and spondylolisthesis. The specific technique is chosen based on the level and nature of the pathology.

mainEntity.name: What are the core patient benefits of choosing Minimally Invasive Spine Surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Patients typically experience less postoperative pain, reduced blood loss, minimal scarring, and faster recovery because the muscles and supporting tissues are preserved. Many MISS procedures allow a shorter hospital stay and an earlier return to normal activity.

mainEntity.name: How long does endoscopic spine surgery take?

acceptedAnswer.text: Most endoscopic spine procedures take 1-3 hours depending on the complexity. Endoscopic discectomy typically takes 60-90 minutes, while more complex procedures like endoscopic ULBD may take 2-3 hours. The shorter operative time contributes to faster recovery.

mainEntity.name: What is the success rate of minimally invasive spine surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Endoscopic spine surgery has success rates of 85-95% for appropriate candidates. Success depends on proper patient selection, accurate diagnosis, and surgeon experience. Dr. Sayuj Krishnan has performed over 500 endoscopic procedures with excellent outcomes.

mainEntity.name: When can I return to work after endoscopic spine surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Most patients can return to desk work within 1-2 weeks after endoscopic spine surgery. Manual labor may require 4-6 weeks. Recovery time varies based on the specific procedure, your overall health, and the physical demands of your job.

mainEntity.name: Is endoscopic spine surgery covered by insurance?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, endoscopic spine surgery is typically covered by most insurance plans when medically necessary. We provide detailed medical estimates and work with insurance companies for pre-authorization. Cashless insurance approvals are available at Yashoda Hospital.

mainEntity.name: What are the risks of minimally invasive spine surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Endoscopic spine surgery has lower risks compared to open surgery, including reduced infection risk, less blood loss, and minimal muscle damage. Potential risks include nerve injury, bleeding, or infection, but these are significantly lower than traditional open procedures.

The specific technique is chosen based on the level and nature of the pathology.

mainEntity.name: What are the core patient benefits of choosing Minimally Invasive Spine Surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Patients typically experience less postoperative pain, reduced blood loss, minimal scarring, and faster recovery because the muscles and supporting tissues are preserved. Many MISS procedures allow a shorter hospital stay and an earlier return to normal activity.

mainEntity.name: How long does endoscopic spine surgery take?

acceptedAnswer.text: Most endoscopic spine procedures take 1-3 hours depending on the complexity. Endoscopic discectomy typically takes 60-90 minutes, while more complex procedures like endoscopic ULBD may take 2-3 hours. The shorter operative time contributes to faster recovery.

mainEntity.name: What is the success rate of minimally invasive spine surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Endoscopic spine surgery has success rates of 85-95% for appropriate candidates. Success depends on proper patient selection, accurate diagnosis, and surgeon experience. Dr. Sayuj Krishnan has performed over 500 endoscopic procedures with excellent outcomes.

mainEntity.name: When can I return to work after endoscopic spine surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Most patients can return to desk work within 1-2 weeks after endoscopic spine surgery. Manual labor may require 4-6 weeks. Recovery time varies based on the specific procedure, your overall health, and the physical demands of your job.

mainEntity.name: Is endoscopic spine surgery covered by insurance?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, endoscopic spine surgery is typically covered by most insurance plans when medically necessary. We provide detailed medical estimates and work with insurance companies for pre-authorization. Cashless insurance approvals are available at Yashoda Hospital.

mainEntity.name: What are the risks of minimally invasive spine surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Endoscopic spine surgery has lower risks compared to open surgery, including reduced infection risk, less blood loss, and minimal muscle damage. Potential risks include nerve injury, bleeding, or infection, but these are significantly lower than traditional open procedures.

mainEntity.name: How soon can I return to desk work after carpal tunnel surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Most patients resume desk work in 7–10 days once sutures are off and discomfort is controlled.

mainEntity.name: Do ulnar nerve symptoms always need surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: No. Night splints and activity changes are tried first; surgery is recommended if weakness progresses or studies show significant block.

mainEntity.name: Do I need surgery for carpal tunnel?

acceptedAnswer.text: Not always. Splints and activity modification help many. Surgery is considered when symptoms persist or weakness appears.

mainEntity.name: Day-care or admission?

acceptedAnswer.text: Often day-care. Your plan depends on nerve involvement and comorbidities.

mainEntity.name: Recovery time?

acceptedAnswer.text: Many desk workers resume light work in 1–2 weeks; grip strength recovers gradually.

mainEntity.name: Peripheral Nerve Surgery
mainEntity.description: Expert peripheral nerve surgery including carpal tunnel release, ulnar nerve decompression, and nerve tumor removal in Hyderabad.

mainEntity.name: Is endoscopic carpal tunnel release better than open surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Both techniques are effective, but endoscopic carpal tunnel release offers advantages including smaller incisions, less post-operative pain, faster recovery, and reduced scarring. However, open release may be preferred for complex cases or when additional procedures are needed.

mainEntity.name: How long does numbness take to improve after nerve decompression?

acceptedAnswer.text: Numbness improvement varies by individual and condition severity. Some patients notice improvement within days to weeks, while others may take 3-6 months for full recovery. Severe cases with long-standing compression may have permanent residual numbness.

mainEntity.name: Can nerve function fully recover after surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Recovery depends on several factors including the duration of compression, severity of damage, and patient age. Early intervention typically yields better outcomes. While many patients achieve significant improvement, complete recovery may not always be possible in severe cases.

mainEntity.name: Do I need EMG/NCS (nerve conduction studies) before surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, EMG/NCS are essential for confirming the diagnosis, localizing the problem, and assessing severity. These tests help determine if surgery is indicated and provide baseline measurements for post-operative comparison.

mainEntity.name: Will insurance cover peripheral nerve decompression surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Most insurance plans cover peripheral nerve surgery when medically necessary. We work with all major insurance providers and TPAs to ensure coverage. Our team will help verify your benefits and handle pre-authorization if required.

mainEntity.name: What are the risks of peripheral nerve surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: While generally safe, potential risks include infection, bleeding, nerve injury, incomplete relief, and recurrence. Dr. Sayuj uses microsurgical techniques, nerve monitoring, and careful patient selection to minimize these risks.

mainEntity.name: When should I consider surgery for carpal tunnel syndrome?

acceptedAnswer.text: Surgery is recommended when conservative treatments (splinting, injections, therapy) fail, symptoms are severe, or there is muscle wasting. Early surgical intervention often provides better outcomes than waiting for severe nerve damage.

isPartOf.name: Dr. Sayuj Krishnan - Neurosurgeon in Hyderabad

mainEntity.name: Robotic Spine Surgery
mainEntity.description: Advanced robotic spine surgery in Hyderabad. High precision, minimal radiation, and faster recovery with AI-driven surgical planning.

mainEntity.name: What is robotic spine surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Robotic spine surgery involves using a robotic arm to assist the surgeon in placing spinal implants (like screws) with extreme precision. The robot does not perform the surgery on its own; it acts as a high-tech guide, enhancing the surgeon’s accuracy and control.

mainEntity.name: Is robotic spine surgery safer than traditional surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, studies show that robotic guidance significantly improves the accuracy of screw placement (up to 99.9%), reducing the risk of nerve injury and revision surgeries. It also lowers radiation exposure for both the patient and the surgical team.

mainEntity.name: Does robotic surgery mean the robot does the operation?

acceptedAnswer.text: No. Dr. Sayuj Krishnan is in full control at all times. The robot is a tool that provides a rigid, precise trajectory for instruments, preventing human tremor or fatigue-related errors during critical steps.

mainEntity.name: Who is a candidate for robotic spine surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: It is ideal for patients requiring spinal fusion, scoliosis correction, tumor surgery, or revision spine surgery. It is especially beneficial for complex anatomies where freehand surgery might be risky.

mainEntity.name: How much does slip disc surgery cost in Hyderabad?

acceptedAnswer.text: Slip disc (herniated disc) surgery costs in Hyderabad range from ₹2,50,000 to ₹4,00,000 for endoscopic discectomy, and ₹2,00,000 to ₹3,50,000 for traditional open discectomy. Endoscopic surgery offers better value with same-day discharge and faster recovery, despite slightly higher initial cost.

mainEntity.name: Is endoscopic discectomy more expensive than open surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Endoscopic discectomy typically costs ₹2,50,000-4,00,000 compared to ₹2,00,000-3,50,000 for open surgery. However, endoscopic surgery often results in lower overall costs due to same-day discharge, reduced medication needs, and faster return to work. The minimally invasive approach provides better value.

mainEntity.name: Does insurance cover slip disc surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, most health insurance plans cover slip disc surgery including endoscopic discectomy. Cashless insurance options are available at Yashoda Hospital. Our team assists with pre-authorization and helps you understand your coverage. Contact us to verify your insurance eligibility.

mainEntity.name: What is spinal decompression surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Spinal decompression is a general term for surgical procedures performed to alleviate pain caused by pinched nerves. Common types include laminectomy (removing bone), discectomy (removing disc), and foraminotomy (widening nerve exit).

mainEntity.name: How much does spinal decompression surgery cost in Hyderabad?

acceptedAnswer.text: The cost typically ranges from ₹1.2 Lakhs to ₹2.5 Lakhs depending on the technique (Endoscopic vs Open), the hospital room category, and whether implants are needed.

mainEntity.name: Is it major surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: It depends on the technique. Dr. Sayuj specializes in "Minimally Invasive Decompression," which uses keyhole incisions (<1cm). This is considered safe, with minimal blood loss and rapid recovery compared to traditional open back surgery.

mainEntity.name: Can I walk after surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes! We encourage walking on the same day or the next morning. Early mobility prevents complications and speeds up healing.

mainEntity.name: What conditions does it treat?

acceptedAnswer.text: It effectively treats Spinal Stenosis (narrowing of canal), Herniated Discs (slip disc), Sciatica, and Spondylolisthesis (slipped vertebrae).

mainEntity.name: What is spinal decompression surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Spinal decompression is a general term for surgical procedures performed to alleviate pain caused by pinched nerves. Common types include laminectomy (removing bone), discectomy (removing disc), and foraminotomy (widening nerve exit).

mainEntity.name: How long is recovery after spinal fusion?

acceptedAnswer.text: Most patients resume desk work in 2–4 weeks; full activity varies by case and surgeon advice.

mainEntity.name: Is fusion permanent?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes. The goal is to permanently stabilize a painful motion segment after diseased disc removal.

mainEntity.name: TLIF vs ACDF?

acceptedAnswer.text: TLIF is used in lumbar spine; ACDF is a cervical procedure. Choice depends on level and symptoms.

mainEntity.name: Spinal Fusion Surgery
mainEntity.description: Expert spinal fusion surgery (TLIF/PLIF) by Dr. Sayuj Krishnan. Stabilization for spondylolisthesis and fractures. Minimally invasive screw fixation.

mainEntity.name: What is spinal fusion surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Spinal fusion is a surgery to permanently connect two or more vertebrae in your spine, eliminating motion between them. It uses screws, rods, and bone grafts to create a solid bridge of bone.

mainEntity.name: When is spinal fusion necessary?

acceptedAnswer.text: It is needed when the spine is unstable, such as in spondylolisthesis (slipped vertebra), fractures, severe arthritis, or after removing a large spinal tumor. Simple back pain rarely needs fusion.

mainEntity.name: Will I lose flexibility?

acceptedAnswer.text: Fusion limits motion only at the fused segment. Since most motion comes from the hip and cervical spine, fusing one or two lumbar levels typically does not noticeably restrict daily activities.

mainEntity.name: What is the success rate?

acceptedAnswer.text: For properly selected patients with instability, success rates are over 90%. Pain relief is significant once the fusion solidifies.

mainEntity.name: How long do implants stay in the body?

acceptedAnswer.text: The titanium screws and rods are designed to stay in your body permanently. They do not trigger metal detectors and rarely need removal unless there is an infection or discomfort.

mainEntity.name: How much does endoscopic spine surgery cost in Hyderabad?

acceptedAnswer.text: The cost of endoscopic spine surgery in Hyderabad typically ranges from ₹2,50,000 to ₹4,00,000 depending on the technique (TESS vs Interlaminar) and hospital category. This includes surgeon fees, theatre charges, and a 1-night hospital stay.

mainEntity.name: What is the cost of titanium spine implants?

acceptedAnswer.text: Spine implants (screws and rods) are charged separately. High-grade Indian titanium implants cost approx. ₹35,000–₹50,000 per level, while imported (US/German) FDA-approved implants range from ₹60,000–₹1,00,000 per level.

mainEntity.name: Is spine surgery covered by insurance in Hyderabad?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, nearly all comprehensive health insurance policies cover spine surgery (discectomy, fusion, laminectomy). We accept cashless claims from major providers like Star Health, HDFC Ergo, Niva Bupa, SBI General, and ICICI Lombard at Yashoda Hospital.

mainEntity.name: Why is endoscopic surgery cost higher than open surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Endoscopic surgery requires specialized disposable kits, high-definition cameras, and advanced burrs, which increases the consumable cost. However, the total cost often balances out due to shorter hospital stays (1 day vs 3-4 days) and faster return to work.

availableAtOrFrom.name: Dr Sayuj Krishnan - Neurosurgeon in Malakpet

mainEntity.name: What is Uniportal Endoscopic Spine Surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: It is an ultra-minimally invasive technique where the entire surgery is performed through a single tiny incision (about 8mm). Both the camera and instruments pass through this single channel, minimising trauma to surrounding muscles compared to biportal or tubular methods.

mainEntity.name: How is it different from Biportal Endoscopy (UBE)?

acceptedAnswer.text: Biportal endoscopy requires two incisions (one for camera, one for instruments). Uniportal uses only one "keyhole". This typically results in even less postoperative pain and a more cosmetic, virtually invisible scar.

mainEntity.name: Am I a candidate for this "Single Hole" surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Most patients with sciatica, slip disc, or spinal stenosis who have not responded to 6 weeks of medication and physiotherapy are candidates. Dr. Sayuj will evaluate your MRI to confirm if the anatomy is suitable for this specific approach.

schemas.name: Same-Day Endoscopic Discectomy in Hyderabad — Case Story

mainEntity.name: Is endoscopic discectomy always better than open surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: No. The safest, most effective approach depends on your anatomy and goals.

mainEntity.name: Can pain return after endoscopic discectomy?

acceptedAnswer.text: There is a small risk of reherniation. Following the rehab plan reduces risk.

mainEntity.name: When can I fly after surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Often after 2–3 weeks in uncomplicated cases, if you can walk and stretch comfortably.

mainEntity.name: Is fusion required with decompression?

acceptedAnswer.text: Not usually for isolated stenosis without instability.

mainEntity.name: How soon can I resume long walks?

acceptedAnswer.text: Many patients build up to longer walks over weeks according to their plan.

mainEntity.name: Will the symptoms recur?

acceptedAnswer.text: Spine degeneration can progress. Core and posture training help maintain results.

schemas.name: MVD for Trigeminal Neuralgia — Case Story (Hyderabad)

mainEntity.name: Is MVD curative?

acceptedAnswer.text: It offers the best chance for durable relief in classic TN with vascular compression; individual results vary.

mainEntity.name: What are the alternatives to MVD?

acceptedAnswer.text: Radiosurgery and percutaneous procedures are options; durability and side effects differ.

mainEntity.name: How long is recovery after MVD?

acceptedAnswer.text: Many daily activities resume in weeks; your plan is individualized.

schemas.name: Back Pain Symptoms & Causes | Dr. Sayuj Krishnan
schemas.description: Comprehensive guide to back pain causes, symptoms, and red flags. Learn when to seek expert neurosurgical care in Hyderabad.

isPartOf.name: Dr. Sayuj Krishnan - Neurosurgeon in Hyderabad

mainEntity.name: Back Pain
mainEntity.description: Comprehensive guide to back pain causes, symptoms, and red flags. Learn when to seek expert neurosurgical care in Hyderabad.

mainEntity.name: When is back pain serious?

acceptedAnswer.text: Back pain is serious if it's accompanied by fever, weight loss, leg weakness, numbness in the groin area, or loss of bladder/bowel control. These require immediate medical attention.

mainEntity.name: What is the difference between muscle pain and disc pain?

acceptedAnswer.text: Muscle pain is usually a dull ache that improves with rest. Disc pain (like a slip disc) is often sharp, shooting, and radiates down the leg (sciatica), often worsening with sitting or bending.

mainEntity.name: Can stress cause back pain?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, emotional stress can cause muscle tension leading to back pain. However, persistent pain should always be evaluated to rule out structural causes.

about.name: Headache
signOrSymptom: Pain on the crown of the head

mainEntity.name: Is pain on the top of my head always serious?

acceptedAnswer.text: Most cases relate to tension or posture. Seek medical care when pain is severe, persistent, or accompanied by neurological symptoms.

mainEntity.name: Can cervical spine problems cause vertex headaches?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes. Cervical radiculopathy and facet arthropathy frequently refer pain to the top of the head. Imaging and examination confirm the diagnosis.

mainEntity.name: Do I need an MRI for head pain?

acceptedAnswer.text: MRI is recommended when headaches persist despite treatment, present with red flags, or occur alongside neurological deficits. Your specialist will advise based on symptoms.

schemas.name: Signs of a Brain Tumor
schemas.description: Identify early warning signs of brain tumours, emergency red flags, and diagnostic steps available in Hyderabad with Dr. Sayuj Krishnan.

isPartOf.name: Dr. Sayuj Krishnan — Brain & Spine Clinic

mainEntity.name: Are all persistent headaches caused by brain tumours?

acceptedAnswer.text: Most headaches are caused by benign conditions such as migraine or tension. Seek specialist evaluation when headaches worsen, occur with neurological symptoms, or feel different from your usual pattern.

mainEntity.name: When should I get an MRI for headache or neurological symptoms?

acceptedAnswer.text: An MRI is recommended when headaches are progressive, accompanied by seizures, vision changes, or neurological deficits. Your neurosurgeon will advise the specific protocol.

mainEntity.name: Can lifestyle changes reverse brain tumour symptoms?

acceptedAnswer.text: Lifestyle modifications support overall health but do not treat tumours. Early medical assessment ensures appropriate imaging and treatment planning.

schemas.name: Advanced Neurosurgical Technology
schemas.description: State-of-the-art neurosurgical technology and innovation including neuronavigation, ROSA DBS, intraoperative monitoring, and minimally invasive techniques for optimal patient outcomes.

mainEntity.name: Is robotic neurosurgery better than traditional surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Robotic assistance (like ROSA DBS) enhances human expertise by providing sub-millimeter precision and stability that is hard to achieve manually. However, the surgeon's judgment and experience remain the most critical factors. Robotics are a tool for safety and accuracy, not a replacement for the surgeon.

mainEntity.name: How does AI help in brain and spine surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: AI assists in preoperative planning by analyzing MRI/CT scans to map tumors and critical pathways. During surgery, AI-driven navigation (Neuronavigation) acts like a GPS, guiding the surgeon to avoid vital structures, reducing risks, and preserving function.

mainEntity.name: Does advanced technology increase the cost of surgery significantly?

acceptedAnswer.text: While advanced technology involves specialized equipment, it often reduces overall costs by minimizing complications, shortening hospital stays, and speeding up recovery. The long-term value in safety and quality of life is significant.
